full_text:
Bangladesh PM flies to India, thousands storm her official residence: Report

Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina was flown to India in a military helicopter on Monday as hundreds of thousands of protesters demanded she resign amid a deadly anti-government stir, according to Reuters citing local sources.

Key Developments:
- Thousands of protesters flooded into the Prime Minister's official residence in Dhaka after her departure
- Army chief General Waker-Uz-Zaman is set to address the nation
- Violent clashes have left more than 100 people dead and hundreds injured
- Nationwide protests continue despite a curfew

Detailed Account:
Sheikh Hasina and her sister Sheikh Rehana left their official residence in Dhaka. A military helicopter reportedly took off at 2:30 p.m. local time, heading towards West Bengal, India.

Sheikh Hasina's son, Sajeeb Wazed Joy, urged security forces to prevent a forceful takeover, stating: "Your duty is to keep our people safe and our country safe and to uphold the constitution."

Protest Details:
- Clashes erupted between protesters demanding Hasina's resignation and ruling party supporters
- Police used tear gas and stun grenades to disperse protesters
- Bangladesh Railways suspended all services indefinitely
- Garment factories closed

Casualties and Impact:
- 14 police officers killed (13 in Sirajganj, 1 in Comilla)
- Over 300 police officers wounded
- Total protest-related deaths since early July estimated at 300

International Response:
- UN human rights chief Volker Turk criticized the "shocking violence"
- India's Ministry of External Affairs issued an advisory for citizens to exercise caution

Military Stance:
The Bangladesh Army stated they "stand by the people," with Army Chief Waker-uz-Zaman noting that the army is "a symbol of the people's trust."
title:
Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and her sister have reportedly fled the country and taken shelter in India. The army chief is in talks with various political parties and stakeholders.

Bangladesh's army chief General Waker-Uz-Zaman is set to address the nation after violent clashes left more than 100 people dead and hundreds more injured. The announcement came as hundreds of student activists took to the streets for a protest march in defiance of a nationwide curfew.

Even as protesters began their "Long March to Dhaka", the army chief was holding talks with leaders of various political parties, including the ruling Awami League and the opposition BNP, and other stakeholders at the army headquarters.
vclaim: Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina allegedly fled to India via military helicopter amid massive anti-government protests. Thousands of protesters reportedly stormed the Prime Minister's official residence in Dhaka after her departure. Violent protests across Bangladesh have resulted in over 100 deaths, including 14 police officers, and hundreds of injuries. The Bangladesh Army declared their support for the people, with the Army chief expected to address the nation. The nationwide protests have led to the suspension of railway services and closure of garment factories despite an imposed curfew.
